body.p:
Hon Thomas E. Bramlett
Governor of Kentucky
At the August Term of the Bracken Circuit Court Saml P. Shover was fined in two cases $60 -- Each for keeping a tipling House -- The cases merit the clemency of the Executive --

The form of Foster Granted Shover license to keep a Coffee House and Shover supposing that he had complied with the law went on and sold liquor without first having obtained license from the County Court of Bracken & paying the State tax. The Court decided that his town license did not protect him and he was fined $60 -- in two cases making $120 -- We feel sure no criminal act was intended by Mr Shover and that he ought to be released of his fine --
Unwilling to lend our name & aid to Excuse real violators of the law, we appeal to your Excellency in this behalf because of its merit --

You will observe from the above communication of the Hon. Jos Doniphan (Judge of the Bracken Circuit Court that Mr Shover obtained & paid for a liscense, & acted in good faith, & without the slightest intention

of violating the law. He believed he was authorized to carry on his business of a "Coffee House" under his liscense. The Liscense as the Judge states was introduced as a defense, but the court properly divided it was no protestion, I think it a meritorious case, very strongly calling for your intervention. If you concur with me, please send to me the evidence of its remission -- At Augusta.

Bracken Cir Ct.
vs
S. R. Shover
2 cases of $60 -- each
Remitted 12th Sept 1863. in part, Tipling

Set 12th
Remit all except $10 of the fine in each case and costs and attys fees
Thos E Bramlette
